unnormalised: Reports are flooding in from companies across India as employees struggle to coordinate with their international counterparts. The culprit? Time zones, those pesky invisible lines that dictate when we can (or can't) schedule that all-important Zoom call. One particularly amusing incident involved Priya Sharma in Mumbai trying to prepone a meeting with a client in New York, only to realize that "prepone" doesn't actually make sense when the client is literally sleeping. The meeting, initially planned for 4 PM IST (Indian Standard Time), got rescheduled for 2 AM EST (Eastern Standard Time). Priya wisely opted for email instead.

The meeting, initially planned for four P-M I-S-T (Indian Standard Time), got rescheduled for two A-M E-S-T (Eastern Standard Time). Priya wisely opted for email instead.

unnormalised: Tech support teams are working overtime to explain the concept of UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) – or rather, attempting to explain it. Let's face it, even Albert Einstein would scratch his head trying to figure out why some places are +5:30 GMT while others are -8 GMT. An IT worker from TCS, Delhi, joked that he now has a PhD in Time Zone Management, after spending 3 hrs. trying to help a confused manager in London understand the differences.

unnormalised: The root cause? Daylight Saving Time, that annual ritual where clocks jump forward and backward, causing mass confusion and existential dread. One tweet read, "Is it 11 AM or 12 PM? My brain hurts. Thanks, DST!" Clearly, the struggle is real. Experts are suggesting a global summit to discuss the possibility of a standardized time zone. Good luck with that, though; we all know how well global summits usually go!
